channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: A Primer on India’s Parliamentary Elections
item.description: What a reader needs to know about the 2014 elections for the Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Supporters of Indian National Congress campaigning at a rally in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Monday.

item.title: Lens Blog: Where the Streets Have No Children
item.description: A chance mention of a small Ecuadorean town with no children and a handful of old residents set Santiago Arcos on a mission to document its dwindling life.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Claudio Quimá sleeping in his hammock. He previously lived with his brother and niece in La Ciénega.

item.title: Pistorius Describes ‘the Moment Everything Changed’
item.description: Testifying for the first time about the shooting of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, the track star said he thought he was protecting her.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius, center, walked toward the courtroom in Pretoria on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. and China Clash Over Contested Islands
item.description: A dispute between Beijing and Tokyo has prompted Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel to warn that the United States would honor treaty obligations to defend its allies.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Europe’s Many Jobless See Little Light Yet From Glimmers of a Recovery
item.description: Even as signs of an economic rebound emerge in the euro zone, the human cost of the five-year downturn continues to rise.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kostas Polychronopoulos offers food to needy people in Monastiraki square in Athens. Mr Polychronopoulos, 49, founded a communal kitchen called Free Food for All in 2012.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Civil Society Activists Face Trial in Beijing
item.description: Ding Jiaxi has been charged with “gathering a crowd to disturb public order” in connection with a series of small demonstrations in Beijing that called for government officials to reveal their personal assets.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Security personnel stood guard on Tuesday outside the courthouse in Beijing where Ding Jiaxi, a lawyer and human rights advocate, went on trial.

item.title: U.S. Contractor Held in Cuba Begins a Hunger Strike
item.description: Saying the United States government has done too little to help him, Alan Gross demanded that President Obama get involved in his case.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Ukraine Moves to Reassert Control Over Restive East
item.description: Ukrainian troops expelled pro-Russian demonstrators from an administration building on Tuesday, as the interim government in Kiev sought to tamp down unrest that some fear might lead to a Russian military invasion.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pro-Russian protesters gathered in front of Ukrainian police officers guarding the Kharkiv regional state administration building on Tuesday after an operation to dislodge pro-Russian separatists from the building.

item.title: Search for Plane’s Black Boxes Will Continue, Officials Vow
item.description: The battery life on the devices is likely running out, leaving the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 racing against time.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 8
item.description: A roundup of Indian election-related news for April 8.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A boy carrying flags of political parties on his bicycle in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Standoff in Taiwan Legislature Appears Close to Resolution
item.description: Speaker Wang Jin-pyng has told demonstrators occupying Taiwan’s legislature that he agrees that a law offering greater oversight of agreements with China should be approved before negotiations resume on a stalled trade pact with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wang Jin-pyng, legislative speaker in Taiwan, greeting protesters.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Lawyers Say They Were Tortured After Protesting ‘Black Jail’
item.description: A lawyer says he and other lawyers were tortured in detention in Jiansanjiang in Heilongjiang Province, where they tried to draw attention to the incarceration of Falun Gong adherents.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Japan’s Central Bank Holds Off More Stimulus
item.description: The Bank of Japan maintained its upbeat view, affirming that the country is on track to meet its 2 percent inflation target by April next year.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Quebecers Reject Separatists, Handing Power to Liberal Party
item.description: An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Québécois on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Parti Québécois Seen Losing Power in the Province
item.description: An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Québécois on Monday. Based on early returns, four television networks forecast a victory for the Liberal Party.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Security Forces Press Offensive Against Separatists
item.description: Pakistani security forces killed 30 separatist militants on Monday in an offensive in Baluchistan, a senior official said, in one of the biggest clashes in months in the province.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Gang Truce Fails to Ease Violence, Officials Say
item.description: The government of El Salvador said Monday that the truce between the country’s main street gangs had not worked, and that killings and attacks against the police had risen again.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: The Vatican: Pope Backs Bank
item.description: Pope Francis gave his backing on Monday to the scandal-tainted Vatican Bank to carry on, provided that it presses ahead with efforts to bring its banking practices up to international standards.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Latvia: Ukraine Crisis Prompts Ban on Russian TV Broadcasts
item.description: Latvia is joining Lithuania in banning Russian state television broadcasts because it found that several programs about the Ukraine crisis were tendentious and not in its national security interests.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Civilians Were Killed by Security Agents, Panel Says
item.description: Nigeria’s National Human Rights Commission said Monday that it had found that security agents were responsible for the unlawful killings of eight civilians in a September raid in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: 2 U.N. Advisers Slain
item.description: A security guard in Somalia’s semiautonomous Puntland region shot to death two consultants working for the United Nations shortly after they had landed at the Galkayo airport on Monday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Wish for Change Animates Voters in India Election
item.description: Narendra Modi, a front-runner for prime minister, is hoping his image as a technocrat will overshadow his past as a hardliner and appeal to an electorate that is tired of dynastic rulers and corrupt lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: A voting station in Majuli, in the northeastern state of Assam. Indians began voting for members of parliament on Monday.

item.title: In Switch, Development Agency Welcomes Business and Technology to Poverty Fight
item.description: Rajiv Shah, head of the United States Agency for International Development, has set off a fierce debate over the way the agency operates and the usefulness of traditional foreign aid.
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rajiv Shah has drawn both criticism and praise for his running of the United States Agency for International Development.

item.title: U.S. Gas Tantalizes Europe, but It’s Not a Quick Fix
item.description: Liquefied natural gas from the United States may hold promise for Europe to reduce its reliance on Russia, but regulatory and market obstacles stand in the way.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cheniere Energy plant in Cameron Parish, La.

item.title: In East Ukraine, Protesters Seek Russian Troops
item.description: Pro-Russian demonstrators occupying a government building in Donetsk also demanded a referendum on seceding from Ukraine, hours after a Ukrainian officer was killed in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pro-Russian protesters gather outside the regional administration building in Donetsk, Ukraine on Monday.
